text: So let her roll David Okay David, he needs to check your voice one more time, if you can maybe count to five or so Four score and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent, etc. Okay does that do it? Yeah, he said that looks good Are we ready? Yes. OK. First of all, Mr. DeCamp, we wondered just a little bit about your origins as a writer back in the late 1930s, such things as or the circumstances that caused you to start writing. Well, in 1937 and 8, I was working in Scranton, Pennsylvania, as principal of the School of Inventing and Patenting of the International Correspondent School. And I had a friend in New York, an old college roommate of mine named John Clark, who was out of a job and looking for one. And in order to continue to eat, he, who was a more faithful reader of the science fiction magazine than I was at that time, wrote a couple of stories. And I used to come in, oh, once or twice a month to New York, and I'd stay at his apartment, and we'd sit up late and plot a couple of these stories. So I gave him some help with them. He sent them to F. Orlin Cremaine, the editor of Astounding, and to everybody's surprise, he sold them. So I thought, well, if he can do that, why can't I? So having plenty of spare time in Scranton, I wrote a couple and sent them in, and to my surprise, they were bought. Well, at that point, I said, why hasn't somebody told me about this before? It sure beats working. So, I wrote a few more stories and articles, sold some, didn't sell others, and then, at the end of the beginning of 1939, I was working at another job as one of the editors on a trade journal in New York, I got fired in an economy purge. So I thought instead of fooling around with these fiddling editorial jobs, why don't I try freelancing? You see, I figured that if I spent five hours a week on my own time writing and made a certain amount of money, if I could spend 50 hours a week at it, I'd make 10 times that much. Well, of course, there's a fallacy there, because you soon run into a law of diminishing returns. But nevertheless, I took the plunge and found that in freelancing, I earned about as much as I had been doing, and I could be my own boss, work at my own pace, work sitting down, and wear out all my old clothes. So except for a couple of temporary jobs and the Second World War in which I was in the Naval Reserve. I've been at it ever since. Those first couple stories you mentioned that were published to your surprise, was one of those hyperphilosity? Yes, hyperphilosity and the isolinguals. What kind of money did you get when you published those? Oh, let me see. I think it was the center word, which got something like 30 or 40 dollars, I suppose. actually if you ask me what was my first published story that is the question that can have any one of three answers if you mean the first one I started writing it was the novel Genus Homo in collaboration with the late Skylar Miller although we started that back around 1936 it took us over two years to finish it and it wasn't published until 1941 If you mean, what was the first story I completed? It was a rather amateurish little caveman story called The Hairless Ones Come, the usual story about the conflict between the Neanderthal men and the Cro-Magnards who overran Europe at the end of the Fourth Glaciation. and that was published in 1939, I believe it was, in a short live magazine of historical adventure called Golden Fleece. So that was the first one finished. Then the first one published was, I believe, the Isolingles. Okay. You obviously have a widespread reputation as a writer of humor, probably the foremost most in the field of science fiction. That's good of you to say so. Do you think of yourself as a humorist? I mean, is that a label that you want or that you agree with? Let's say that I'm not an exclusive professional humorist of the type of the late P.G. Woodhouse, for example. But on the other hand, I do try to liven up most of my fiction with a generous sprinkling of humor. Of course, remember that although people generally refer to me as a science fiction writer, the reason is mainly that I made my early reputation in that field. Actually, fiction is only about half of my output, the rest being science, history, biography, literary criticism, and so on. And of the fictional half, aside from five historical novels that I've written, about half is science fiction in a strict sense and half is fantasy. Only about a quarter of my output is really science fiction in a strict sense. Yeah, no, I understand that. But back to humor for just a moment. Many critics and readers and commentators, whatever, have said that science fiction and humor don't mix well. A good science fiction humorous story or novel is sort of a rarity. What would be your comment about that? Well, all I can say is that it is true that there aren't a great many humorous stories in that field. But then, of course, there aren't a great many humorous stories than any genre of fiction. Some people do it, and some people don't. Now, back in, before the First World... the Second World War, pardon me, I'm not that old quite yet, but before the Second World War, of the active science fiction writers in the country, there were only two who were considered humorous science fiction writers. And I was one, and Henry Kutner was the other. Curiously enough both Henry and I in our private lives were rather serious solemn fellows. For a number of years I've been a fan of your Harold Shay stories, the ones you collaborated with Fletcher Pratt on. If I understand right now, the first one of those was The Roaring Trumpet, published around 1940 or so Yes. Okay, how did that collaboration with Fletcher Pratt start? Fletcher Pratt was a military and naval historian, among other things, and he ran a naval war game in his apartment in New York City. Later they moved to a hired hall when the game got too large. In which people crawled around on the floor pushing little model boats, warships, models the real ships, which Fletcher whittled out at his desk while he was waiting for the next sentence to come. They were made out of balsa wood and wires and pins and things. And I was also a naval buff, a regular reader of Jane's fighting ships and so forth, and I could tell you what was the armament of the French terrible class, five 5.5 inch guns, and so on. So, so was John Clarke. And he got in touch with Fletcher, being more aggressive, let's say, and less shy than I in such matters. He went around and called on him, and presently was enrolled in the Naval War Game. And then he brought me around to meet Fletcher, and I was enrolled and was a regular war game player. Well, Fletcher was at that time an established and active writer, and I was a struggling young pro, you might say. So John said to me, hey, Fletcher says he would like to see you. He has an idea for some stories. So I went around to Fletcher's, and he proposed that he and I collaborate on a series of stories based upon this far-out theory that you can slip into any universe you want to by manipulating the symbols of symbolic logic. I had been studying symbolic logic a little with all its cuter symbols and things. So, okay, we went to it. And that is how the five Harold Shea stories originated, as well as the other Pratt-de-Capt collaborations. One thing that's sort of interested me about that particular collaboration, it seems to me that humor is a very, I guess, a personal thing. I've always wondered how that kind of a writing process worked. For instance, did you write a story and he go over it? Did you do alternate stories? How is the actual mechanics of that? Our method of collaboration, that is to say the one that we found that worked the best for us, was that he and I would get together on an afternoon usually in his apartment and thresh out story ideas. He would come up with one and I'd say, no, no, that's not logical for this or that reason. Or I'd say, well, it seems to me see that that's the same storyline that Kuttner had just last year, such and such a magazine, so forth and so on. And finally, we get a story more or less beaten into shape. And I'd make notes in shorthand, which I had taught myself, and I'd take them home and I'd write out a synopsis of the story and submit that to Fletcher and he would make any additions or changes that he thought desirable. then I'd type the rough draft and give it to him, and he would type the final draft. I have found in collaborations in general that it's usually better for the younger writer of the pair to do the rough than the older one, the final. The reason being that the younger writer is apt to have more energy and more facility, but the older one, having been around longer, longer has a sharper critical sense of spotting illogicalities, infelicities of expression and things of that sort, feeding them out. Very good. None of those stories had anything to do with Campbell, did it? John W. Campbell as an editor, those were entirely separate from him, weren't they? Well, John Campbell published the first three of the Harold Shay novels. Harold Shay, none of his modern things work. The matches, the guns. In other words, there's an internal consistency in the world, even though magic works. That's right. Was that your own idea? That was the common idea. I mean, both Fletcher and I I had long since agreed that, right from the start, that the most effective in writing fantasy, you have to be even more careful about internal consistency than you do in writing a realistic story. Because the reader's credulity is already stretched like a rubber band, you see. And if you put extra strain on it by having some obvious contradiction, it's going to snap. That boy, you'll probably stop reading. Okay, good. Right. Just my observation that a lot of the science fantasy that was being written back then especially did not have that kind of consistency. That is quite right. And I consider myself fairly good at following a train of logic and spotting cases where people commit inconsistencies of that sort. As for example, one colleague of mine with whom I have collaborated, on one night he will have a full moon and on the next night he will have a new moon. Well, you can't do that because it takes two weeks to get from one state to the other. All right, yes, I agree entirely. In the Harold Shea stories as in many of the other novels you've written, at least in the science-fantasy area. My observation is that your humor comes from the unexpected things that happen when you put, say, a modern man back into a world of legend or myth. One of the basic elements of humor, in my estimation, is the element of surprise or incongruity. In other words, a derby hat on a London businessman and is not funny, because they all wear them. But a derby hat on Julius Caesar is, you see, because it's incongruent. And that is a very considerable factor in humor. And to make that incongruity, I guess, obvious or effective, you had to construct, I guess, very realistic or very accurate kinds of backgrounds. Say, if it happened in the ancient world or mythological world, you had to develop a highly realistic context for it. That's right. Where did your knowledge, your background in ancient history and mythology and so forth come from? Did you have to research those things heavily? Actually, I've always been a very heavy reader. I was reading Darwin's Origin of Species through at the age of seven, and things like that. And I had a pretty good historical and mythological knowledge, But actually, for the roaring trumpet, Fletcher knew a good deal more about that than I, because he was an enthusiast for the northerne thing, as William Morris called it, and belonged to a group that got together in Boston and read Icelandic sagas to each other in the original. Well, therefore, he was way ahead of me in the matter of Norse mythology, Then for the second story, it was played in the world of Spencer's Fairy Queen, and I had never read the Fairy Queen, so I sat down and dutifully plowed right through it. I never did have quite the enthusiasm for it that Fletcher did. I found it pretty tedious for long stretches, but nevertheless, he thought highly of it, and he went through it. And then for the third one, why we, I knew something about Ariosto's Orlando Furioso, although I'd never read it through, but it wasn't very difficult to get hold of a set and read it. And that furnished the material layer. Well, then we, after the Second World War, we sent Harold to the world of the Finnish Kallivala. and that was simply a matter of getting the Everyman's Library edition and reading through that and taking notes. And we finally had him end up where he wanted to go all along which is in the mythological Ireland of Coorcholin and Queen Mays. And I already knew a fair amount about that but I read up some more and so we got the stories. What about some of your more historical places like the Rome of Less Darkness Fall? Did you attempt to make that a picture of how 6th century Rome might have been? Yes, I did. I read everything I could get my hands on it from, all the way from the original sources, such as Procopius, and the letters of, what's his name, Cassiodorus, which are available, and the various modern works on the final period, the period of the fall of the West Roman Empire and the barbarian era that followed. Yeah, the reason I ask that is one time I read a critic or a commentator on that book, and he'd assumed or made the statement that he thought it might have been an alternate universe, but I thought that was incorrect. No, it was not intended to be, although I'll have to confess to one minor error. After the book came out, I got a letter from a professor at Dobby at Columbia University, who mind you, saying that he'd read the book and enjoyed it greatly, but did I realize that on page such and such, where I had a couple of my characters speaking Gothic, I realized that I had one of them use the nominative case where he should have used the vocative. did you go back and change it I don't remember. I think I did but I'm not sure. It was just a matter of dropping an S off the end I have another question on that book it's not often I get a chance to ask an author about his intentions or his purposes maybe it's not a fair question but some people have said I've read this that you had a serious theme to that work that can one man change the past for the better I'm not sure if that was intended or if that's even a fair question, but did you have that kind of a theme behind it? I took that as my assumption as to whether it's so or not. I don't know. I don't think anyone else knows either because there's such a large factor of luck in all these historical developments. If Napoleon had fallen off his horse and broken his neck early in his career, what would have happened? And history is full of things like that where what looks like it's going to be an amazing career is cut short by some adventitious circumstance. However, my primary purpose in writing fiction has always been to entertain. And everything else takes a secondary place. Now, I don't say that a little preaching, propaganda for causes that I personally admire like wildlife conservation, let's say, or my personal opinions of prejudices don't sneak in now and then. But nevertheless, the main purpose is entertainment. Some people have said that, oh well, such and such a story by DeCamp is a satire, satirical. Well, I don't consider myself a satirist. In other words, I don't write with the intention of holding up some human institution or form of action to ridicule in the serious hope of getting people to change it. But on the other hand, the human scene around me is so full of dramatic and absurd and comical features that it's only natural to use them and put them in my stories. You have beautifully anticipated my next question, which was going to be that I did see a strain of gentle satire in your work, and I was going to ask you to comment, which you have. well as I say you don't if you really look around you over a good many years you see so many funny things that you don't have to exercise great ingenuity or imagination in order to get an entertaining story out of it just to add a little bit to that though one of your later books The Great Fetish the copy I have was published in 1978 my personal response to that was that there was more of a bite, more of a purpose to the satire it seemed to me in that book, particularly on, say, evolution and religion and so forth. Yes, well you see, I'm the fellow who wrote the definitive history of the Scopes evolution trial in Dayton, Tennessee in 1925. The book is called The Great Monkey Trial, and it just went out of print a double day a year or so ago, after having been in print for, let's say, a dozen or fifteen years. And it was a book that got quite a lot of attention when it came out, most of it happy to say favorable. And it seemed to me that really, I also did an article for the Scientific American a few years ago on the Epperson case. The article was called The End of the Monkey War, and it's about the how the anti-evolution law of the state of Arkansas was appealed up to the US Supreme Court, and the court declared it unconstitutional. I followed that case rather closely and got to know the principles, such as the Epperson's and such, and having been in... And my wife and I have also written a juvenile biography of Charles Darwin, Darwin and His Great Discovery, published by MacMellan. I think that's a print. But having put so much time in on it, it just seemed to me that with the setup of this particular story, well, you know, there's a chance for a switch there. How about it if the equivalent of our creationists today were the ones who were right for the reasons set forth in the story? So I took that as my assumption and worked it out from there. Okay, that's very good. The book started with the trial, and I immediately thought of the Scopes trial. Yeah, exactly. Well, it's a switch on the Scopes trial, essentially. Okay. I'm not sure I'm going to pronounce this right, but the Govegan's Bar? That's correct. Okay. Of course, that was another collaboration with Pratt, the story of tales from Govegan's Bar. I was curious about the antecedents for that kind of a frame tale, you know, with the bar and the recurring characters and so forth. Was that something you came up with yourself, or was there an antecedent for that? It did have an antecedent, and that was the Jorkin stories of Lord Dunsany, of which he wrote five volumes. And they include some very fine little stories. Indeed, I was familiar with the stories. I don't remember whether either Fletcher or I was consciously influenced by their example when we started our Gewagan's Bar Series. Fletcher just said, well, let's write some short stories of this and that sort laid in the bar, you know, barroom tall tales. And he also would write Duncane, and I dare say he had jorkins at the back of his mind too. By coincidence, our friend Arthur C. Clarke over in England was just beginning his Tales of the White Heart at the same time, which is also a set of far-room tall tales. Neither of us knew about what the other was doing. Okay, yeah, his... I thought your book antedated his, or was before the Tales of the White Heart. I don't know offhand what the date of publication of Tales of the White Heart was, But in any case, I do believe it's correct that both Art and Pratt and I were working on these series at the same time. At least they overlapped. After all, we wrote these stories over a period of several years before they were collected in book form. They appeared in various magazines, including the old weird tales, even. Hmm. In its last years, it unfolded in 1954. Would you say that there is anything that would not work as humor in science fiction or science fantasy? For instance, I have in mind, say, heroic fantasy of the Conan type. Would it be possible to retain the heroic grandness, the environment of that kind of story, and still write it humorously? well, you couldn't get the same effect that Robert Howard did with his Conan because in Robert Howard's original Conan stories, there is hardly any humor only in a couple of stories is there a faint gleam of it here and there and when I collaborate with present day Conan stories let us say Carter, why he has to call me down now and then because I just have a natural tendency to stick a little humor in now and then I've been doing it so long natural but it should not be done because it spoils the general effect. Now as for my own stories in that genre well I have no hesitation about putting humor in and my heroes are in general not supermen they have to be pretty able fellows but I I try to make them realistic, that is, with the usual assortment of virtues and vices and strengths and weaknesses. Because that's the kind of character that I personally find it easier to believe in when I read it. When you write a science fiction story that you intend to be humorous, do you write it as a humorous science fiction story or as a humorous story that is science fiction? Well I think that's merely a matter of definition I never really thought of it I have not I have not been successful in writing non-imaginative humor in other words writing stories in a realistic setting and primarily humorous I did take a crack at one once back around 1948 I guess it was, just shortly after the Hitlerian war. And I wrote a whole novel that was sort of intended to be in the general vein of P.G. Woodhouse and Thorne Smith, whom I was quite an admirer. But unfortunately, when it was finished, everybody who saw it shuddered. They said it stank, and I'm afraid they were right. It's never been published from that day to this, and it probably would be better for my reputation if it never is. What's been your most popular work in terms of sales? Do you have any estimation of that? Oh, goodness, that's hard to say, and it also depends upon which kind of writing you're talking about. In fiction, I suppose probably one or the other of the Conan stories. But then since most of those I've written in collaboration, those that I have written, why I suppose half the credit ought to go to the collaborator. in nonfiction, I think the most sales are those of the ancient engineers. Okay, I only had one more question on humor. I'd like to ask you a little bit about Conan afterwards. Sure. Is there anything special or unique about science fiction or science fantasy that makes it a unique feel for a humorist? anything that you couldn't do in other forms of fiction? Well, you can, of course, because of the fact that you're much less limited as to your settings and your basic assumptions than you are in realistic fiction. It gives you unlimited opportunities for working the essential factors of humor, such as surprise and incongruity. So I'd say on the whole that it's a very good field for humor, but in a way that certain other fields are not. For example, I don't get a laugh out of funny war stories, for example, because to me war is a pretty serious business and not a proper subject for levity. Okay, to switch direction for just a minute here, your background, as I've read, is engineering, say your college background, sort of a practical science background, and you've written books on inventions and so forth. Of course, that's led to many non-fiction books, too, as you pointed out. Does that kind of background influence your science fiction? Yes, it does. If you read any of my stories laid in an imaginary milieu, you will notice a good deal more attention paid to the nuts and bolts element of the background, the various gadgets that people use and how they work. You'll notice a good deal more of that than you will in a similar story by one of my contemporaries. As for example, the last Krishna novel that I had published The Hostages Dear at one point where the protagonist Fergus Reith is looking for a means to escape incidentally he is one who gets married to a beautiful extraterrestrial princess and then wishes like hell he could get out of it somehow, but she's a great boy, and is only interested in one thing. And so while he is down on the waterfront with his bodyguard to see that he doesn't bolt, a fire breaks out and presently, a crew of firemen come running up with a fire engine. Now the fire engine, however, is the type that was actually used in the ancient world, and I get that through my readings in the history of science and technology, which is to say it's just a big tub with handles at the corners and a pump in the middle, and the firemen carry it by the handles, they set it down in front of where the fire is, they organize a bucket brigade to fill the tank, and then they heave up and down on the pump handles to squirt water at the fire, and that is what you might call the predecessor of a modern steam-powered fire engine. Okay, some of those books where you write about the inventions, say inventions in their management, or inventions, patents, and so forth, Heroic Age of American Invention, are those still in print? Well, no, let me think. I believe that inventions, patents, and their management is in print. In fact, I rather dread the day that Litton Industries will call me up and say, Hey, DeCamp, you've got to rewrite the chapter on copyright in light of the new copyright law. The Heroic Age of American Invention, no, that's been out of print for quite a good long while. The Ancient Engineers is available from Valentine in paperback. mm-hmm sadly two of my books ancient engineers and great cities of the ancient world sold much sold better in Germany than they did in this country great cities didn't didn't make much of a splash in America but in Germany it made the best teller list what's your reputation in Europe now that you brought that up are you do you sell pretty well over there overall in Europe hmm Yes, pretty well, mainly in the United Kingdom and Germany. Also, quite a lot of stuff, my stuff has come out in Italy. Those will be translations, correct? Yeah. Yeah. I've had a few translations in Japan, even. Maybe this isn't a fair question to ask of an author, but is it a question of enjoyment or the mood you're in as to whether you write, say, a science fiction or a fantasy book or a nonfiction one? Is there an enjoyment involved with one over the other, or is it a duty that you feel? Well, let's say that when I finish one big job, I like to tackle another one in a different field, just for a change. In other words, when I've written the novel, well, next time around, maybe I'll try an article or a nonfiction book. When I finish a nonfiction book, I want to get back to fiction. Right now, for example, I'm completing my own autobiography, and my wife is doing the final draft of the biography of Robert Howard. And, uh, I have a couple of novels, one science fiction and one fantasy in mind, which I want to get to as well as several short stories. Okay. On the Conan material, I guess, heroic fantasy or whatever, or sword and sorcery, whatever the genre, Now, you had written Heroic Fantasy, that type, before you took up with Conan, right? That is right. In fact, I was writing it before the term was invented and before I'd even heard of Robert Howard. How did you get involved with his material? With Howard's material? Right. I went up to New York, it was around the end of 1950, and let me see, I think it was the Naval War Game at the Pratt's apartment or something. No, it wasn't. It was the party at Pratt's apartment. And he handed me a copy of Conan the Conqueror, found in hardback, published by Gnome Press. And he said, here, take this along. I think you might find it interesting. I don't care much for it myself, but Gnome's. So I took it. It seems that Martin had, by inadvertence, sent Fletcher two review copies. Fletcher gave me one. I started reading it on the train going home and was hooked right away. I kept on until I'd read the thing through, and then I read it through again. Then I got hold of John Clark, who I had heard casually mention Conan once or twice, but he never tried to tell me on the idea, and I said, hey, what is this? John told me about it. he had a found file of tear sheets of the original Conan stories and weird tales which he lent to me and I devoured them and then a year later I found some unpublished Conan manuscripts in the custody of the agent for the Howard Literary Estate and I read them and arrangements were made with the Howard Ayers and the agent for me to edit them and arrange for publication and then on things have gone on and on and built up from that. As far as you know, is there any more of the Howard material which has not been published relating to Conan, that papers or story ideas and so forth that have not been... Not so far as I know, but the person to ask about that is not me, but Glenn Lord, in Pasadena, Texas. Do you envision yourself writing any more Conan material, you know, the original Conan material? I don't make any promises or predictions. Right now, let's say I do not have anything like that in mind. I am involved in the novelization of the Conan the Barbarian movie. But when that is out of the way, why there are no present plans for anything more, not that I expect to be idle. I have enough to do to keep me busy for a whole other lifetime. I was going to ask you about the movie, your involvement with that. Are you hired as a consultant or a screenwriter? I'm supposed to be a technical advisor. Do you have any information on it? I mean, when it's going to be out or if it's going to be true to the books? We are at present shooting in Spain. They expect to finish in May, and the movie should be released about 13 to 14 months from now. That's the last I've heard, but there are always flippage in these things, you know. You've written this kind of material for so long. Probably your perspective is better than anybody else's on this. Doesn't it seem that heroic fantasy or sword and sorcery is extremely popular now? Huge reading public. Has that... have you wondered about that, or wondered if it's going to wear off? Is it a fad or the reasons for it? These things always tend to go in waves, and they go up and down and may build up further. Eventually there's bound to be a dip in public interest, but that doesn't mean that it'll just disappear. it'll decline little and then maybe rise up again in another 20 or 50 years. You can't really predict. I think that part of the popularity of the genre was a reaction to certain trends in fiction following the Second World War, such as the fondness for heavily subjective psychological or psychiatric stories, very sentimental stories, stories glorifying the little man, the anti-hero, you know, that hopeless little jerk who can't do anything right who has no brains or brawn or character and whose only function is to suffer and suffer? Well, I think people got sort of tired of that after a while. So then, between the paperback publication of the Conan stories, for which I can claim the credit, I'm the one who sold them, and the paperback publication of Tolkien's Lord of the Rings, which was the other major factor in launching this boom, Why? That got people to reading heroic fantasy on a large scale, which they are still doing. Okay, you mentioned earlier the biography of Robert E. Howard. Yes. I read somewhere where the title of that was going to be Dark Valley Destiny. Is that correct? That is correct. When is that scheduled for release? We haven't finished the work on it yet, and we don't have a contract. In fact, one of these months, we shall turn the thing over to our agent and say, go to it, Eleanor, see what's the best deal you can get. But a great deal depends upon who owns what of the phenomenal literary properties at that time, and that becomes a matter of finance and litigation and things of that sort. I would assume that you were probably as knowledgeable on Howard as anybody living. In your research, in your study of the man, what kind of person did you find him to be? Well, let's say that I'd like to have met him, which I physically could have in the early 1930s if I had known about him, but I'd never heard of him at that time. But, and he and I had a good many interests in common in history, mythology, and so on And we might have gotten along fine If I'd gone to see him in Cross Plains, maybe I have sometimes fantasized He could have taught me to box while I taught him to fence I was on my college team, you see fencing It wasn't very good, but they knew it were the others So, on the other hand, it's very possible that we couldn't have stood each other, because you can't tell how the chemical combination of two personalities is going to work out. And Robert was a person who, one of his outstanding personality quirks was a tendency to form dislikes and bitter hatreds on little or no pretext. He hated all sorts of people. he was a well, let's say that Conan is an obvious idealization of just a minute What is that?

segments.text: So let her roll David
Okay David, he needs to check your voice one more time, if you can maybe count to five or so
Four score and seven years ago our fathers brought forth on this continent, etc.
Okay
does that do it?
Yeah, he said that looks good
Are we ready?
Yes.
OK. First of all, Mr. DeCamp, we wondered just a little bit about your origins as a writer back in the late 1930s, such things as or the circumstances that caused you to start writing.
Well, in 1937 and 8, I was working in Scranton, Pennsylvania, as principal of the School of Inventing and Patenting of the International Correspondent School.
And I had a friend in New York, an old college roommate of mine named John Clark, who was out of a job and looking for one.
And in order to continue to eat, he, who was a more faithful reader of the science fiction magazine than I was at that time, wrote a couple of stories.
And I used to come in, oh, once or twice a month to New York,
and I'd stay at his apartment, and we'd sit up late
and plot a couple of these stories.
So I gave him some help with them.
He sent them to F. Orlin Cremaine,
the editor of Astounding,
and to everybody's surprise, he sold them.
So I thought, well, if he can do that, why can't I?
So having plenty of spare time in Scranton,
I wrote a couple and sent them in,
and to my surprise, they were
bought.
Well, at that point, I said,
why hasn't somebody told me about this before?
It sure beats working.
So, I wrote a few
more stories and articles,
sold some, didn't sell others,
and
then,
at the end of
the beginning of 1939,
I was working at another
job as one of the
editors on a trade journal in New York, I got fired in an economy purge. So I thought instead
of fooling around with these fiddling editorial jobs, why don't I try freelancing? You see,
I figured that if I spent five hours a week on my own time writing and made a certain amount
of money, if I could spend 50 hours a week at it, I'd make 10 times that much. Well, of course,
there's a fallacy there, because you soon run into a law of diminishing returns. But nevertheless,
I took the plunge and found that in freelancing, I earned about as much as I had been doing,
and I could be my own boss, work at my own pace, work sitting down, and wear out all my old clothes.
So except for a couple of temporary jobs and the Second World War in which I was in the Naval
Reserve. I've been at it ever since.
Those first couple stories you mentioned that were
published to your surprise, was one of those hyperphilosity? Yes,
hyperphilosity and the isolinguals.
What kind of money did you get when you published those?
Oh, let me see. I think it was the center word, which
got something like 30 or 40 dollars, I suppose.
actually if you ask me
what was my first published
story
that is the question that can have
any one of three answers
if you mean the first one I started
writing
it was the novel Genus Homo
in collaboration with the late
Skylar Miller
although we started that back around
it took us over two years to finish it
and it wasn't published until 1941
If you mean, what was the first story I completed?
It was a rather amateurish little caveman story called The Hairless Ones Come,
the usual story about the conflict between the Neanderthal men and the Cro-Magnards
who overran Europe at the end of the Fourth Glaciation.
and that was published in 1939,
I believe it was,
in a short live magazine
of historical adventure
called Golden Fleece.
So that was the first one finished.
Then the first one published
was, I believe,
the Isolingles.
Okay.
You obviously have
a widespread reputation
as a writer of humor,
probably the foremost
most in the field of science fiction.
That's good of you to say so.
Do you think of yourself as a humorist?
I mean, is that a label that you want or that you agree with?
Let's say that I'm not an exclusive professional humorist
of the type of the late P.G. Woodhouse, for example.
But on the other hand, I do try to liven up
most of my fiction with a generous sprinkling of humor.
Of course, remember that although people generally refer to me as a science fiction writer,
the reason is mainly that I made my early reputation in that field.
Actually, fiction is only about half of my output, the rest being science, history, biography,
literary criticism, and so on.
And of the fictional half, aside from five historical novels that I've written, about half is science fiction in a strict sense and half is fantasy.
Only about a quarter of my output is really science fiction in a strict sense.
Yeah, no, I understand that.
But back to humor for just a moment.
Many critics and readers and commentators, whatever,
have said that science fiction and humor don't mix well.
A good science fiction humorous story or novel is sort of a rarity.
What would be your comment about that?
Well, all I can say is that it is true
that there aren't a great many humorous stories in that field.
But then, of course, there aren't a great many humorous stories
than any genre of fiction.
Some people do it, and some people don't.
Now, back in, before the First World...
the Second World War, pardon me,
I'm not that old quite yet,
but before the Second World War,
of the active science fiction writers in the country,
there were only two
who were considered humorous science fiction writers.
And I was one, and Henry Kutner
was the other. Curiously
enough
both Henry and I
in our private lives
were rather serious
solemn fellows.
For a number of years I've been a fan
of your Harold Shay stories, the ones
you collaborated with Fletcher Pratt on.
If I understand right now, the first
one of those was The Roaring Trumpet, published
around 1940 or so
Yes.
Okay, how did that collaboration with Fletcher Pratt start?
Fletcher Pratt was a military and naval historian, among other things,
and he ran a naval war game in his apartment in New York City.
Later they moved to a hired hall when the game got too large.
In which people crawled around on the floor pushing little model boats,
warships, models the real
ships, which Fletcher whittled
out at his desk while he was waiting for the
next sentence to come. They were made out of
balsa wood and wires and pins
and things.
And
I was also a naval
buff, a regular reader
of Jane's fighting ships and so forth,
and I could tell you what
was the armament of the French
terrible class, five
5.5 inch guns, and so
on.
So, so was John Clarke.
And he got in touch with Fletcher, being more aggressive, let's say, and less shy than
I in such matters.
He went around and called on him, and presently was enrolled in the Naval War Game.
And then he brought me around to meet Fletcher, and I was enrolled and was a regular war game
player.
Well, Fletcher was at that time an established and active writer, and I was a struggling
young pro, you might say.
So John said to me, hey, Fletcher says he would like to see you.
He has an idea for some stories.
So I went around to Fletcher's, and he proposed that he and I collaborate
on a series of stories based upon this far-out theory
that you can slip into any universe you want to
by manipulating the symbols of symbolic logic.
I had been studying symbolic logic a little with all its cuter symbols and things.
So, okay, we went to it.
And that is how the five Harold Shea stories originated,
as well as the other Pratt-de-Capt collaborations.
One thing that's sort of interested me about that particular collaboration,
it seems to me that humor is a very, I guess, a personal thing.
I've always wondered how that kind of a writing process worked.
For instance, did you write a story and he go over it?
Did you do alternate stories?
How is the actual mechanics of that?
Our method of collaboration,
that is to say the one that we found
that worked the best for us,
was that he and I would get together
on an afternoon usually in his apartment
and thresh out story ideas.
He would come up with one and I'd say,
no, no, that's not logical for this or that reason.
Or I'd say, well, it seems to me
see that that's the same storyline that Kuttner had just last year, such and such a magazine,
so forth and so on.
And finally, we get a story more or less beaten into shape.
And I'd make notes in shorthand, which I had taught myself, and I'd take them home
and I'd write out a synopsis of the story and submit that to Fletcher and he would make
any additions or changes that he thought desirable.
then I'd type the rough draft and give it to him,
and he would type the final draft.
I have found in collaborations in general
that it's usually better for the younger writer of the pair
to do the rough than the older one, the final.
The reason being that the younger writer
is apt to have more energy and more facility,
but the older one, having been around longer,
longer has a sharper critical sense
of spotting illogicalities,
infelicities of expression
and things of that sort,
feeding them out.
Very good.
None of those stories
had anything to do with Campbell, did it?
John W. Campbell as an editor,
those were entirely separate from him, weren't they?
Well, John Campbell published
the first three of the
Harold Shay novels.
Harold Shay, none of his
modern things work.
The matches, the guns.
In other words, there's an
internal consistency in the
world, even though magic
works.
That's right.
Was that your own idea?
That was the common idea.
I mean, both Fletcher and I
I had long since agreed that, right from the start,
that the most effective in writing fantasy,
you have to be even more careful about internal consistency
than you do in writing a realistic story.
Because the reader's credulity is already stretched like a rubber band, you see.
And if you put extra strain on it by having some obvious contradiction,
it's going to snap.
That boy, you'll probably stop reading.
Okay, good. Right.
Just my observation that a lot of the science fantasy that was being written back then especially did not have that kind of consistency.
That is quite right.
And I consider myself fairly good at following a train of logic and spotting cases where people commit inconsistencies of that sort.
As for example, one colleague
of mine with whom I have
collaborated, on one night
he will have a full moon
and on the next night
he will have a new moon.
Well, you can't do that
because it takes two weeks
to get from one state
to the other.
All right, yes, I agree entirely.
In the Harold Shea stories
as in many of the other
novels you've written,
at least in the science-fantasy area.
My observation is that your humor
comes from the unexpected things that happen
when you put, say, a modern man back into a world of legend or myth.
One of the basic elements of humor, in my estimation,
is the element of surprise or incongruity.
In other words, a derby hat on a London businessman
and is not funny, because they all wear them.
But a derby hat on Julius Caesar is, you see,
because it's incongruent.
And that is a very considerable factor in humor.
And to make that incongruity, I guess, obvious or effective,
you had to construct, I guess, very realistic
or very accurate kinds of backgrounds.
Say, if it happened in the ancient world or mythological world,
you had to develop a highly realistic context for it.
That's right.
Where did your knowledge,
your background in ancient history
and mythology and so forth come from?
Did you have to research those things heavily?
Actually, I've always been a very heavy reader.
I was reading Darwin's Origin of Species
through at the age of seven,
and things like that.
And I had a pretty good historical
and mythological knowledge,
But actually, for the roaring trumpet, Fletcher knew a good deal more about that than I,
because he was an enthusiast for the northerne thing, as William Morris called it,
and belonged to a group that got together in Boston and read Icelandic sagas to each other in the original.
Well, therefore, he was way ahead of me in the matter of Norse mythology,
Then for the second story, it was played in the world of Spencer's Fairy Queen, and I
had never read the Fairy Queen, so I sat down and dutifully plowed right through it.
I never did have quite the enthusiasm for it that Fletcher did.
I found it pretty tedious for long stretches, but nevertheless, he thought highly of it,
and he went through it.
And then for the third one, why we, I knew something about Ariosto's Orlando Furioso, although I'd never read it through, but it wasn't very difficult to get hold of a set and read it.
And that furnished the material layer.
Well, then we, after the Second World War, we sent Harold to the world of the Finnish Kallivala.
and that was simply a matter of getting the Everyman's Library edition
and reading through that and taking notes.
And we finally had him end up where he wanted to go all along
which is in the mythological Ireland of Coorcholin and Queen Mays.
And I already knew a fair amount about that
but I read up some more
and so we got the stories.
What about some of your more historical places
like the Rome of Less Darkness Fall?
Did you attempt to make that a picture of how 6th century Rome might have been?
Yes, I did.
I read everything I could get my hands on it from, all the way from the original sources,
such as Procopius, and the letters of, what's his name, Cassiodorus, which are available,
and the various modern works on the final period,
the period of the fall of the West Roman Empire
and the barbarian era that followed.
Yeah, the reason I ask that is one time I read a critic
or a commentator on that book,
and he'd assumed or made the statement
that he thought it might have been an alternate universe,
but I thought that was incorrect.
No, it was not intended to be,
although I'll have to confess to one minor error.
After the book came out,
I got a letter from a professor at Dobby
at Columbia University, who mind you,
saying that he'd read the book and enjoyed it greatly,
but did I realize that on page such and such,
where I had a couple of my characters speaking Gothic,
I realized that I had one of them use the nominative case
where he should have used the vocative.
did you go back and change it
I don't
remember. I think I did but I'm not
sure. It was just a matter of dropping an S
off the end
I have another question on that book
it's not often I get a chance to ask an author
about his intentions
or his purposes
maybe it's not a fair question but
some people have said I've read this
that you had a serious theme to that
work that
can one man change the past
for the better
I'm not sure if that was intended
or if that's even a fair question,
but did you have that kind of a theme
behind it?
I took that as my assumption
as to whether it's so or not.
I don't know. I don't think anyone else knows either
because there's such a large
factor of luck
in all these historical developments.
If Napoleon had fallen off his horse
and broken his neck early in his career,
what would have happened?
And history is full of things like that where what looks like it's going to be an amazing career is cut short by some adventitious circumstance.
However, my primary purpose in writing fiction has always been to entertain.
And everything else takes a secondary place.
Now, I don't say that a little preaching, propaganda for causes that I personally admire like wildlife conservation, let's say,
or my personal opinions of prejudices don't sneak in now and then.
But nevertheless, the main purpose is entertainment.
Some people have said that, oh well, such and such a story by DeCamp is a satire, satirical.
Well, I don't consider myself a satirist.
In other words, I don't write with the intention of holding up some human institution or form of action
to ridicule in the serious hope of getting people to change it.
But on the other hand, the human scene around me is so full of dramatic and absurd and comical features
that it's only natural to use them and put them in my stories.
You have beautifully anticipated my next question,
which was going to be that I did see a strain of gentle satire in your work,
and I was going to ask you to comment, which you have.
well as I say you don't
if you
really look around you over a good
many years you see so many
funny things
that you don't have to exercise
great ingenuity or imagination
in order to get an entertaining
story out of it
just to add
a little bit to that though
one of your later books
The Great Fetish
the copy I have was published in 1978
my personal response to that was that there was more of a bite, more of a purpose to the
satire it seemed to me in that book, particularly on, say, evolution and religion and so forth.
Yes, well you see, I'm the fellow who wrote the definitive history of the Scopes evolution
trial in Dayton, Tennessee in 1925. The book is called The Great Monkey Trial, and it just
went out of print a double day
a year or so ago, after having
been in print for,
let's say, a dozen or
fifteen years.
And it was a book that got quite a lot of
attention when it came out, most of it
happy to say favorable.
And
it seemed to me that
really, I also
did an article for the Scientific American
a few years ago on the Epperson
case. The article was called
The End of the Monkey War, and it's about
the
how the anti-evolution law of the state of Arkansas was appealed up to the US Supreme Court,
and the court declared it unconstitutional.
I followed that case rather closely and got to know the principles, such as the Epperson's and such,
and having been in...
And my wife and I have also written a juvenile biography of Charles Darwin,
Darwin and His Great Discovery, published by MacMellan.
I think that's a print.
But having put so much time in on it,
it just seemed to me that with the setup of this particular story,
well, you know, there's a chance for a switch there.
How about it if the equivalent of our creationists today
were the ones who were right for the reasons set forth in the story?
So I took that as my assumption and worked it out from there.
Okay, that's very good.
The book started with the trial, and I immediately thought of the Scopes trial.
Yeah, exactly.
Well, it's a switch on the Scopes trial, essentially.
Okay.
I'm not sure I'm going to pronounce this right, but the Govegan's Bar?
That's correct.
Okay.
Of course, that was another collaboration with Pratt, the story of tales from Govegan's Bar.
I was curious about the antecedents for that kind of a frame tale,
you know, with the bar and the recurring characters and so forth.
Was that something you came up with yourself, or was there an antecedent for that?
It did have an antecedent, and that was the Jorkin stories of Lord Dunsany,
of which he wrote five volumes.
And they include some very fine little stories.
Indeed, I was familiar with the stories.
I don't remember whether either Fletcher or I
was consciously influenced by their example
when we started our Gewagan's Bar Series.
Fletcher just said,
well, let's write some short stories
of this and that sort laid in the bar,
you know, barroom tall tales.
And he also would write Duncane,
and I dare say he had jorkins at the back of his mind too.
By coincidence, our friend Arthur C. Clarke
over in England was just beginning his Tales of the White Heart
at the same time, which is also a set of far-room tall tales.
Neither of us knew about what the other was doing.
Okay, yeah, his...
I thought your book antedated his, or was before the Tales of the White Heart.
I don't know offhand what the date of
publication of Tales of the White Heart was,
But in any case, I do believe it's correct that both Art and Pratt and I were working on these series at the same time.
At least they overlapped.
After all, we wrote these stories over a period of several years before they were collected in book form.
They appeared in various magazines, including the old weird tales, even.
Hmm.
In its last years, it unfolded in 1954.
Would you say that there is anything that would not work as humor in science fiction or science fantasy?
For instance, I have in mind, say, heroic fantasy of the Conan type.
Would it be possible to retain the heroic grandness, the environment of that kind of story, and still write it humorously?
well, you couldn't get the same effect
that Robert Howard did with his Conan
because in Robert Howard's original Conan
stories, there is hardly any humor
only in a couple of stories is there a faint gleam
of it here and there
and when I collaborate
with present day Conan stories
let us say Carter, why
he has to
call me down now and then
because I just have a natural tendency
to stick a little humor in now and then
I've been doing it so long
natural but it should not be done
because it spoils the general
effect. Now as for my
own stories
in that genre
well I have no hesitation about putting
humor in
and my heroes are in general not supermen
they have to be pretty
able fellows but I
I try to make them realistic, that is, with the usual assortment of
virtues and vices and strengths and weaknesses.
Because that's the kind of character that I personally find it easier to believe in when I
read it.
When you write a science fiction story that you intend to be humorous,
do you write it as a humorous science fiction story or as a
humorous story that is science fiction?

Well I think that's merely a matter of definition I never really thought of it I have not I have not been successful in writing non-imaginative humor in other words writing stories in a realistic setting and primarily humorous
I did take a crack at one once back around 1948 I guess it was, just shortly after the Hitlerian war.
And I wrote a whole novel that was sort of intended to be in the general vein of P.G. Woodhouse and Thorne Smith, whom I was quite an admirer.
But unfortunately, when it was finished, everybody who saw it shuddered.
They said it stank, and I'm afraid they were right.
It's never been published from that day to this,
and it probably would be better for my reputation if it never is.
What's been your most popular work in terms of sales?
Do you have any estimation of that?
Oh, goodness, that's hard to say,
and it also depends upon which kind of writing you're talking about.
In fiction, I suppose probably one or the other of the Conan stories.
But then since most of those I've written in collaboration,
those that I have written,
why I suppose half the credit ought to go to the collaborator.
in nonfiction, I think the most sales are those of the ancient engineers.
Okay, I only had one more question on humor.
I'd like to ask you a little bit about Conan afterwards.
Sure.
Is there anything special or unique about science fiction or science fantasy
that makes it a unique feel for a humorist?
anything that you couldn't do in other forms of fiction?
Well, you can, of course, because of the fact that you're much less limited as to your settings
and your basic assumptions than you are in realistic fiction.
It gives you unlimited opportunities for working the essential factors of humor,
such as surprise and incongruity.
So I'd say on the whole that it's a very good field for humor,
but in a way that certain other fields are not.
For example, I don't get a laugh out of funny war stories, for example, because to me war is a pretty serious business and not a proper subject for levity.
Okay, to switch direction for just a minute here,
your background, as I've read,
is engineering, say your college background,
sort of a practical science background,
and you've written books on inventions and so forth.
Of course, that's led to many non-fiction books, too,
as you pointed out.
Does that kind of background
influence your science fiction?
Yes, it does.
If you read any of my stories
laid in an imaginary milieu,
you will notice a good deal more attention paid
to the nuts and bolts element of the background,
the various gadgets that people use and how they work.
You'll notice a good deal more of that
than you will in a similar story
by one of my contemporaries.
As for example,
the last
Krishna novel that I had published
The Hostages Dear
at one point
where the
protagonist
Fergus Reith is
looking for
a means to escape
incidentally he is
one who gets married

somehow,
but she's a great boy, and is only interested

so
while he is

to see that he doesn't bolt,
a fire breaks out
and
presently, a crew of
firemen come running up with
a fire engine. Now the fire engine,
however, is the type that was
actually used in the ancient world, and I get that through my readings in the history
of science and technology, which is to say it's just a big tub with handles at the corners
and a pump in the middle, and the firemen carry it by the handles, they set it down
in front of where the fire is, they organize a bucket brigade to fill the tank, and then
they heave up and down on the pump handles to squirt water at the fire, and that is what
you might call the predecessor of a modern steam-powered fire engine.

mm-hmm

Yes, pretty well, mainly in the United Kingdom and Germany.

Yeah.
Yeah.
I've had a few translations in Japan, even.
Maybe this isn't a fair question to ask of an author,
but is it a question of enjoyment or the mood you're in
as to whether you write, say, a science fiction or a fantasy book
or a nonfiction one?
Is there an enjoyment involved with one over the other,

Well, let's say that when I finish one big job,
I like to tackle another one in a different field,
just for a change.
In other words, when I've written the novel,
well, next time around, maybe I'll try an article or a nonfiction book.
When I finish a nonfiction book, I want to get back to fiction.
Right now, for example, I'm completing my own autobiography, and my wife is doing the final draft of the biography of Robert Howard.
And, uh, I have a couple of novels, one science fiction and one fantasy in mind, which I want to get to as well as several short stories.
Okay. On the Conan material, I guess, heroic fantasy or whatever, or sword and sorcery, whatever the genre,
Now, you had written Heroic Fantasy, that type,

That is right.
In fact, I was writing it before the term was invented
and before I'd even heard of Robert Howard.
How did you get involved with his material?
With Howard's material?
Right.
I went up to New York, it was around the end of 1950,
and let me see, I think it was the Naval War Game
at the Pratt's apartment or something.
No, it wasn't. It was the party at Pratt's apartment.
And he handed me a copy of Conan the Conqueror,
found in hardback, published by Gnome Press.
And he said, here, take this along.
I think you might find it interesting.
I don't care much for it myself, but Gnome's.
So I took it.
It seems that Martin had, by inadvertence,
sent Fletcher two review copies.
Fletcher gave me one.
I started reading it on the train going home and was hooked right away.
I kept on until I'd read the thing through, and then I read it through again.
Then I got hold of John Clark, who I had heard casually mention Conan once or twice,
but he never tried to tell me on the idea, and I said, hey, what is this?
John told me about it.
he had
a found
file of

which he

and I

I don't make any promises or predictions.

I was going to ask you about the movie,
your involvement with that.

I'm supposed to be a technical advisor.
Do you have any information on it?
I mean, when it's going to be out

We are at present shooting in Spain.
They expect to finish in May, and the movie should be released about 13 to 14 months from now.
That's the last I've heard, but there are always flippage in these things, you know.
You've written this kind of material for so long.
Probably your perspective is better than anybody else's on this.
Doesn't it seem that heroic fantasy or sword and sorcery is extremely popular now?
Huge reading public.
Has that... have you wondered about that, or wondered if it's going to wear off?
Is it a fad or the reasons for it?
These things always tend to go in waves, and they go up and down and may build up further.
Eventually there's bound to be a dip in public interest,
but that doesn't mean that it'll just disappear.
it'll decline little and then maybe rise up again in another 20 or 50 years.
You can't really predict.
I think that part of the popularity of the genre
was a reaction to certain trends in fiction following the Second World War,
such as the fondness for heavily subjective psychological or psychiatric stories,
very sentimental stories, stories glorifying the little man, the anti-hero,
you know, that hopeless little jerk who can't do anything right
who has no brains or brawn or character
and whose only function is to suffer and suffer?
Well, I think people got sort of tired of that after a while.
So then, between the paperback publication of the Conan stories,
for which I can claim the credit, I'm the one who sold them,
and the paperback publication of Tolkien's Lord of the Rings,
which was the other major factor in launching this boom,
Why? That got people to reading heroic fantasy on a large scale, which they are still doing.
Okay, you mentioned earlier the biography of Robert E. Howard.
Yes.
I read somewhere where the title of that was going to be Dark Valley Destiny.
Is that correct?
That is correct.
When is that scheduled for release?
We haven't finished the work on it yet, and we don't have a contract.
In fact, one of these months, we shall turn the thing over to our agent
and say, go to it, Eleanor, see what's the best deal you can get.
But a great deal depends upon who owns what
of the phenomenal literary properties at that time,
and that becomes a matter of finance and litigation
and things of that sort.

I was on my college team, you see fencing
